title.narrative: IFC Investment Climate TF Phase II 2018-23

description.narrative: Insatsen syftar till att med teknisk assistens hjälpa berörda Etiopiaks myndigheter att stärka landets investeringsklimat, med fokus på följande områden: 1) Investeringsklimat i Oromia och Amhaha 2) Turism och servicesektorer 3) Doing Business rating (DBR) 4) Trade facilitation 5) Investeringspolicy och främjande. Resultaten förväntas materialiseras huvudsakligen i form av förändringar i policies och regelverk, som i sin tur förbättrar DBR och reducerar transaktionskostnader för näringslivet (besparingar för privata sektorn). Högre mål är primärt att dessa besparingar stimulerar tillväxt och skapar jobb för biståndets målgrupper.

The intervention seeks to use Technical Assistance to strengthen the business enabling environment in Ethiopia. The main focus areas are 1) Sub-regional investment climate in Oromia and Amhara, 2) Tourism and Services sectors, 3) Improved international Doing Business Rating (DBR) 4) Trade facilitation, 5) Investment Policy and Promotion. The results are expected to materialize primarily in the areas of improved policies and regulations, which in turn are expected to improve DBR and reduce transaction costs for the prive sector. At the higher level this is primarily expected to stimulate growth for firms with expansion and employment effects for the targets groups of development cooperation.

The overall objective is stated broadly and in a non-standard way. As stated in the most recent proposal (September 2018), the core objective is to: To "push for business and investment climate reforms… consistent with this broad objective [of developing] … a robust private sector" with specific objectives denoted as "Pillars”" · Pillar I: Improving the Doing Business Environment – improving the economy wide investment environment that affects decisions to open and operate a business. · Pillar II: Expanding Market Opportunities – delivering sector and market-specific solutions to allow firms to expand and compete in domestic and international trade. · Pillar III: Investment Facilitation and Export Competitiveness – investment promotion and regulatory reform work on priority sectors including tailored regulatory advocacy on export sectors. Five projects are planned to achieve these overall objectives, each with their own specific objectives: Project 1: The Sub National Investment Climate project seeks to: a) “strengthen regional investment promotion, retention and expansion in selected/target sectors to be defined in consultation with each regional government; b) enhance regional business service delivery through streamlined business regulatory and tax administration procedures; and c) strengthen inter-agency coordination and public-private dialogue for improved regional investment climate.” Project 2: Ethiopia Tourism Sector Competitiveness project seeks to “improve the performance of tourism sector in Ethiopia through better management of meetings Conferences and Events (MICE), stopover tourism, and digital marketing.” Project 3: Ethiopia Doing Business project seeks “to improve Ethiopia’s Business Climate and make it work for all classes and types of business” (“improve Ethiopia’s DTF score by a minimum of 5 points”) Project 4: Ethiopia Trade Facilitation project seeks to “address trade logistics issues that are holding back trade in Ethiopia.” Project 5: Investment Policy and Promotion (IPP) project (IPP phase II) seeks to: a) “further consolidate and expand the institutional and legal reforms realized through phase I of the project through the development of supporting policies and institutions for conducive investment policy making and promotion, b) reduce legal and administrative barriers to foreign investment, c) strengthen and broaden targeted investment promotion and facilitation in priority sectors through the use of a value chain approach (target sectors will be defined through further consultation with the Government of Ethiopia (GoE), and d) enhance investment retention and expansion through increased investor confidence and targeted investment climate improvements (including reforms aimed at enhancing export competitiveness of investments).

participating-org.narrative: IFC/International Finance Corporation/The World Bank Group
IFC/International Finance Corporation/The World Bank Group

tag.narrative: 8.2 - Achieve higher levels of economic productivity through diversification, technological upgrading and innovation, including through a focus on high-value added and labour-intensive sectors.
8.2 - Uppnå högre ekonomisk produktivitet genom diversifiering, teknisk uppgradering och innovation, bland annat genom att fokusera på sektorer med högt förädlingsvärde och hög arbetsintensitet.

description.narrative:
The Ethiopia Private Sector Development Multi-Donor Initiative (MDI) is a joint funding platform that aims to promote private sector development in Ethiopia. The MDI has two pillars: Pillar I – Investment Climate (IC), which seeks to improve the investment climate; and Pillar II – Access to Finance (A2F), which aims to enhance access to finance for, and promote investments targeting, SMEs. Current donors to the MDI are Canada, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, the United Kingdom, and the United States. Since Sweden has two contributions to two different programs (IC II and A2F), this statement of the overall reports, report for the contribution on IC phase II, but the reporting is joint for both pillars. All semi-annual narrative and financial reports were delivered on time and are complete fullfilling the conditions in the agreement. COVID-19 Statement: IFC has continued to review and assess the impact of the pandemic on its advisory portfolio and teams continue to adapt work programs where needed. Overall, most projects are proceeding with implementation, albeit with some modifications and extensions in some cases. IFC continues to adapt and respond to the situation through adjusting delivery modes where possible, including implementing innovative approaches. Monitoring the pandemic’s impact on advisory program delivery remains an ongoing effort and IFC will continue to keep development partners updated. The donors initiated a series of updating meetings first half of 2020 in order to keep up with the impact, and have a dialogue with IFC that they needed to adjust their programming to the current circumstances. As a result less international consultants were hired, more local consultants were hired, and less travel. General Comment Investment Climate in Ethiopia: Ethioipa's launching of Home-grown economic reform in september 2019, opened up for a stronger alignment with what the MDI: IC phase II is trying to achieve- to improve the echo-system for private sector development in Ethiopia, to remove red tape and bottle neckes, to encourage investments, and facilitate access to finance. In a way, previous government resistance to the private sector is now removed, and IFC will most likely be able to harvest what has been planted and treated with resistance earlier. After a year and a half of into the economic reform agenda, various reforms and policies have been adopted that will contribute to an improved echo system in the business environment in Ethiopia and there is no doubt that IFC has made this happen with their technical support and expertise.
Investment Climate (IC) Pillar Phase II. Phase II which initiated in 2017 is funded by Sweden, Netherlands and United Kingdom and includes five distinct projects: Ethiopia Doing Business Ethiopia Subnational Investment Climate Ethiopia Tourism Ethiopia Trade Facilitation Project Ethiopia Investment Policy and Promotion Of these five projects, two are set to conclude this year (Ethiopia Tourism and Ethiopian Subnational Investment Climate). T he most successful to-date at the Ethiopia Doing Business and the two Investment projects. According to the IFC, the 2021 Doing Business report is expected to recognize six reforms (starting a business, getting credit, registering property, getting a construction permit, paying tax and getting electricity). : Other reforms anticipated as being in the “pipeline” are likely to further advance the ease of doing business and trading (commercial code, electronic single window (eSW), electronic customs management system (ECMS), tax e-filing, building risk directive). Around 2,400 investors have applied for licenses in Amhara and Oromia and significant national-level regulatory reforms were achieved which reduced physical inspections of goods going through customs’ red channel, reducing the amount from 60 percent of the goods to 24.55 percent, against a target of 30 percent. More limited results have been achieved in Tourism, a sector which has been greatly affected by COVID.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
